'''Carlos Alcaraz Garfia''' (born 5 May 2003) is a Spanish professional [[tennis]] player. He is currently ranked world No. 1 in singles by the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP). Alcaraz has won ten [[ATP Tour]]-level singles titles, including the [[2022 US Open – Men's singles|2022 US Open]] and four [[ATP Tour Masters 1000|Masters 1000]] titles. With the US Open win, Alcaraz became the youngest man to top the singles rankings at 19 years, 4 months, and 6 days old, and the first teenager in the Open Era to top the men's rankings.<ref name="ATP1">{{cite web |title=Alcaraz becomes youngest world No. 1 in Pepperstone ATP rankings history |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-climbs-to-world-no-1-us-open-2022 |website=ATP Tour |access-date=September 12, 2022 |date=September 11, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-ruud-us-open-2022-final |title=Alcaraz wins US Open title & rises to world No. 1 |website=ATP Tour |access-date=September 12, 2022 |date=September 11, 2022}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Carlos Alcaraz Youngest Year-End ATP No. 1 Presented By Pepperstone In History {{!}} ATP Tour {{!}} Tennis |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/carlos-alcaraz-year-end-no-1-2022 |access-date=2022-11-26 |website=ATP Tour}}</ref>

As a junior, Alcaraz was ranked as high as world No. 22 and won two titles on the [[ITF Junior Circuit]]. After turning professional in 2018, he won three titles on the [[ITF Men's World Tennis Tour]] and four on the [[ATP Challenger Tour]] and broke into the top 100 in rankings in May 2021. Two months later, Alcaraz reached his first ATP Tour final at the [[2021 Croatia Open Umag – Singles|2021 Croatia Open]], an [[ATP Tour 250|ATP 250]] tournament, where he won his first title. He later entered the top 50 after reaching the quarterfinals at the following US Open and won the year-end [[2021 Next Generation ATP Finals]] in [[Milan]]. After winning his first [[ATP Tour 500|ATP 500]] title at the [[2022 Rio Open – Singles|Rio Open]] in February 2022, Alcaraz won his first Masters 1000 title at the [[2022 Miami Open – Men's singles|Miami Open]] and his second ATP 500 title at the [[2022 Barcelona Open Banc Sabadell – Singles|Barcelona Open]] in April, propelling him into the top 10.{{TOC limit|2}}

==Early life==
Carlos Alcaraz Garfia was born on May 5, 2003, in [[El Palmar, Murcia]], [[Spain]] to parents Carlos Alcaraz González and Virginia Garfia Escandón. He has three siblings. He started playing tennis at the Real Sociedad Club de Campo de Murcia where his father was the tennis academy director. In 2018, he began playing at [[Juan Carlos Ferrero]]'s Equelite JC Ferrero Sport Academy.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.equelite.com/jcferrerero-nuevo-coach-carlos-alcaraz/ |title=Juan Carlos Ferrero será el nuevo coach de Carlos Alcaraz |date=7 August 2018 |website=Equelite JC Ferrero Sport Academy |language=es}}</ref>

==Professional career==
===2020: ATP debut===
In February 2020, at the age of 16, Alcaraz made his ATP main-draw debut at the [[2020 Rio Open|Rio Open]] after receiving a wildcard for the singles main draw. There, he defeated [[Albert Ramos Viñolas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/ATP_Tennis/81432/carlos-alcaraz-grabs-2020-rio-open-wild-card-for-an-atp-debut/ |title=Carlos Alcaraz grabs 2020 Rio Open wild card for an ATP debut |website=Tennis World USA}}</ref> Alcaraz was ultimately defeated in the second round by [[Federico Coria]].

===2021: First title, Next-Gen Finals champion, top 35===
[[File:Carlos Alcaraz.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Alcaraz at the [[2021 French Open]]]]

At age 17, Alcaraz qualified for the main draw of the [[2021 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]], making him the youngest participant in the men's singles.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sportsfinding.com/alcaraz-follows-in-the-footsteps-of-djokovic-nadal-and-federer/78180/ |title=Alcaraz follows in the footsteps of Djokovic, Nadal and Federer |date=15 January 2021}}</ref> He won his [[Grand Slam (tennis)|Grand Slam]] debut defeating fellow qualifier [[Botic van de Zandschulp]] in straight sets before losing in the second round to [[Mikael Ymer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-australian-open-2021-tuesday |title=17-Year-Old Carlos Alcaraz Wins Grand Slam Debut at Australian Open | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref>

Alcaraz became the youngest match winner in the [[Madrid Open (tennis)|Madrid Open]]'s history, defeating [[Adrian Mannarino]] as a wildcard and breaking then-18-year-old [[Rafael Nadal]]’s record from 2004. In the second round, he lost to five-time champion Nadal on Alcaraz's 18th birthday.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-mannarino-madrid-2021-monday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Sets Rafael Nadal Clash in Madrid | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2021-monday-reaction |title=Alcaraz on 'Dream' Nadal Clash: 'It's the Best Birthday Present' | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Rafael_Nadal/97643/rafael-nadal-loses-madrid-open-age-milestone-to-17yearold-carlos-alcaraz/ |title=Rafael Nadal loses Madrid Open age milestone to 17-year-old Carlos Alcaraz}}</ref>
By winning the biggest title of his career until then at the [[2021 Open de Oeiras III]] Challenger tournament, he entered the top 100 as the youngest player at the age of 18 on 24 May 2021.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-2021-oeiras-challenger-title |title=Carlos Alcaraz Claims Historic Fourth Challenger Crown | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis-tourtalk.com/74206/alcaraz-triumphs-at-oeiras-open-challenger |title=Alcaraz Triumphs at Oeiras Open Challenger |date=22 May 2021}}</ref>

At the [[2021 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]], Alcaraz reached the third round of a Grand Slam for the first time in his career by defeating [[Nikoloz Basilashvili]].

In July 2021, he reached his first ATP final at the [[2021 Croatia Open Umag – Singles|2021 Croatia Open Umag]], defeating top seed [[Albert Ramos-Viñolas]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/ramos-vinolas-alcaraz-gasquet-altmaier-umag-2021-sf |title=Carlos Alcaraz Makes History in Umag, Reaches First ATP Tour Final | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> He then won his maiden ATP title by defeating [[Richard Gasquet]] and becoming the youngest tour-level champion since 18-year-old [[Kei Nishikori]] won the Delray Beach Open in 2008. Alcaraz was the youngest Spaniard to win an ATP Tour title since Nadal claimed his first trophy in Sopot in 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-gasquet-umag-2021-final |title=18-Year-Old Carlos Alcaraz Wins First ATP Tour Title in Umag | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref>

At [[2021 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]], he lost in the second round to [[Daniil Medvedev]]. At the [[2021 Winston-Salem Open|Winston-Salem Open]], Alcaraz reached the round of 16 defeating qualifier [[Alexei Popyrin]], and his second tour-level quarterfinal of the season defeating fourth seed [[Marton Fucsovics]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-tiafoe-winston-salem-2021-wednesday |title=Alcaraz Rebounds to Foil Fucsovics' Bid in Winston-Salem | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> He defeated [[Marcos Giron]] to reach the semifinals,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/article/sports-tennis-us-open-tennis-championships-winston-salem-36e3b51a216b02e05d6f75949ef77779 |title=Ivashka, Ruusuvuori, Ymer advance in Winston-Salem Open |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=27 August 2021}}</ref> where he lost to [[Mikael Ymer]].

At the [[2021 US Open – Men's singles|US Open]], Alcaraz defeated world No. 3 [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] in a fifth-set tiebreak to reach the fourth round in the biggest win of his career.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/alcaraz-upsets-tsitsipas-reach-us-open-fourth-round-2021-09-03/ |title=Alcaraz upsets Tsitsipas to reach U.S. Open fourth round |newspaper=Reuters |date=4 September 2021 |last1=Keating |first1=Steve}}</ref> At 18 years of age, Alcaraz became the youngest man in a Grand Slam fourth round since 17-year-old [[Andrei Medvedev (tennis)|Andrei Medvedev]] at the [[1992 French Open – Men's singles|1992 French Open]], and the youngest man in the US Open fourth round since 17-year-old [[Michael Chang]] and 18-year-old [[Pete Sampras]] in [[1989 US Open – Men's singles|1989]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/tsitsipas-alcaraz-us-open-2021-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Records Biggest Career Win, Shocks Stefanos Tsitsipas in US Open Thriller | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/32141025/daniil-medvedev-cruises-pablo-andujar-fourth-round-us-open |title=Alcaraz, 18, stuns Tsitsipas; Tiafoe tops Rublev |date=3 September 2021}}</ref> He then reached the quarterfinals by defeating qualifier [[Peter Gojowczyk]]. Alcaraz became the youngest US Open men's quarterfinalist in the [[Open Era]], the youngest at the tournament since 18-year-old [[Thomaz Koch]] in [[1963 U.S. National Championships – Men's singles|1963]], and the youngest Grand Slam men's singles quarterfinalist since 18-year-old Michael Chang at the [[1990 French Open – Men's singles|1990 French Open]]. He then lost to [[Félix Auger-Aliassime]] via retirement in the second set in the quarterfinals after injuring his leg.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/the-latest-fernandez-19-reaches-us-open-women-s-semis |title=The Latest: Alcaraz says leg muscle made him stop at Open}}</ref>

At the [[Erste Bank Open]], Alcaraz defeated world No. 7 [[Matteo Berrettini]], marking his second win over a top-10 player.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-berrettini-zverev-felix-vienna-2021-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Upsets Berrettini in Vienna Classic, Reaches SFS | ATP Tour | Tennis |newspaper=Atp Tour}}</ref> As a result, he made his debut as the youngest player in the top 35 on 1 November. During his [[2021 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles|Paris Masters]] run, Alcaraz defeated French wildcard [[Pierre-Hugues Herbert]] in three thrilling sets in the first round.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/Tennis_Interviews/104476/carlos-alcaraz-reacts-to-surviving-thriller-versus-pierrehugues-herbert-in-paris-/ |title=Carlos Alcaraz reacts to surviving thriller versus Pierre-Hugues Herbert in Paris}}</ref> He then defeated [[Jannik Sinner]] in straight sets in the second round, marking his third win over a top-10 player.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-paris-2021-wednesday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Stops Jannik Sinner's Nitto ATP Finals Tilt | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> In the third round, he was defeated by [[Hugo Gaston]] in straight sets.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/gaston-wins-17-straight-points-to-beat-alcaraz-paris-2021 |title=Hugo Gaston Wins 17 Straight Points to Beat Alcaraz Paris 2021 | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref>

At the [[Next Generation ATP Finals|Next Gen ATP Finals]], Alcaraz defeated [[Brandon Nakashima]], [[Juan Manuel Cerúndolo]], and [[Holger Rune]] in the round-robin stage. He advanced to the semifinals undefeated, where he defeated [[Sebastian Baez]]. He then advanced to the final, where he defeated [[Sebastian Korda]] to win the championship.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-rune-milan-2021-tuesday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Downs Rune in Milan | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-nakashima-milan-2021-wednesday |title=Alcaraz Secures SF Berth in Milan | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-cerundolo-milan-2021-thursday |title=Ruthless Carlos Alcaraz Sinks Juan Manuel Cerundolo in Milan | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-baez-milan-2021-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Sets Sebastian Korda Showdown in Milan | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref>

===2022: First major, youngest ever world No. 1 and year-end No. 1===
{{Main article|2022 Carlos Alcaraz tennis season}}

Seeded for the first time in a Grand Slam at No. 31, Alcaraz reached the third round of the [[2022 Australian Open – Men's singles|Australian Open]] before losing in five sets to [[Matteo Berrettini]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-australian-open-2022-monday-reaction |title=What Carlos Alcaraz Has Done Quicker Than the Big Three | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref>

Seeded seventh at the [[2022 Rio Open – Singles|Rio Open]], Alcaraz won his first ATP 500 title defeating [[Diego Schwartzman]] in the final.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-atp-rankings-21-february-2022 |title=Carlos Alcaraz Rises to Career-High After Rio de Janeiro Title | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> As a result, he made his debut into the top 20 in the singles rankings on 21 February 2022. In [[2022 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells]], Alcaraz reached his first [[ATP Tour Masters 1000|Masters 1000]] quarterfinal and semifinal, defeating the defending champion [[Cameron Norrie]] before losing to [[Rafael Nadal]].

Seeded 14th at the [[2022 Miami Open - Men's singles|Miami Open]], Alcaraz defeated 6th seed [[Casper Ruud]] to win his first Masters 1000 title. He became the youngest men's champion in the tournament's history.

At the [[2022 Monte-Carlo Masters – Singles|Monte-Carlo Masters]], Alcaraz lost in the second round to [[Sebastian Korda]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/apr/13/monte-carlo-masters-tennis-cameron-norrie-dan-evans |title=Carlos Alcaraz exits in windy Monte Carlo against unseeded Sebastian Korda |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=13 April 2022 |accessdate=9 Sep 2022}}</ref> At the [[2022 Barcelona Open Banc Sabadell - Singles|Barcelona Open]], Alcaraz defeated top seed Stefanos Tsitsipas in the quarterfinals<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennisworldusa.org/tennis/news/On_the_ATP_results_with/112794/atp-barcelona-carlos-alcaraz-downs-stefanos-tsitsipas-and-writes-history/ |title=ATP Barcelona: Carlos Alcaraz downs Stefanos Tsitsipas and writes history}}</ref> to enter the top 10 in rankings for the first time on 25 April.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-tsitsipas-barcelona-2022-qf |title=Carlos Alcaraz Stays Perfect vs. Stefanos Tsitsipas, Reaches Barcelona SFS | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/atp-barcelona/2022/carlos-alcaraz-beats-stefanos-tsitsipas-in-barcelona-open-thriller-to-guarantee-spot-in-world-s-top-_sto8896118/story.shtml |title=Carlos Alcaraz beats Stefanos Tsitsipas in Barcelona Open thriller to guarantee spot in world's top 10 |publisher=Eurosport |date=22 April 2022 |accessdate=2022-05-07}}</ref> He became the 20th teen to break into top 10 overall since rankings were established in 1973, and the youngest since Rafael Nadal also on 25 April 2005.<ref>{{cite tweet |author=ATP Media Info |user=ATPMediaInfo |number=1517611987915755521 |date=22 April 2022 |title=On Monday, @AlcarazCarlos03 will become 20th teen to break into Top 10 overall and 1st since @Andy_Murray in 2007 (#ATP Rankings est. 1973). Twelve went on to become No. 1. Alcaraz will be 9th-youngest player to break into Top 10 overall and youngest since @RafaelNadal in 2005. https://t.co/fGve9gaJ8V |language=en |access-date=12 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220716054625/https://twitter.com/ATPMediaInfo/status/1517611987915755521 |archive-date=16 July 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tennisnow.com/News/2022/April/Alcaraz-Downs-Tsitsipas-Again,-Reaches-Barcelona-S.aspx |title=Alcaraz Downs Tsitsipas Again, Reaches Barcelona Semis |publisher=Tennis Now |date=2022-04-22 |accessdate=2022-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/carlos-alcaraz-top-10-feature-april-2022 |title='Straight-A Student' Carlos Alcaraz Makes Historic Top 10 Breakthrough | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> Alcaraz later defeated [[Pablo Carreño Busta]] to win the title.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-carreno-busta-barcelona-2022-final |title=Amazing Alcaraz Wins Barcelona Title |website=ATP Tour |date=24 April 2022}}</ref>

A day after his 19th birthday at the [[2022 Mutua Madrid Open – Men's singles|Madrid Open]], he defeated 5-time Madrid champion, world No. 4 and third seed [[Rafael Nadal]] in the quarterfinals to become the first teenager to defeat him on clay.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/nadal-alcaraz-madrid-2022-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Takes Out Rafael Nadal in Madrid | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> The following day, he went on to beat the world No. 1 and top seed [[Novak Djokovic]] in the semifinals for his 6th straight top-10 win, and became the youngest player to win a match against a world No. 1 since 2004. He also became the first player to ever beat Djokovic and Nadal back-to-back on clay.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-alcaraz-madrid-2022-saturday |title=Alcaraz Takes Out Djokovic, Reaches Madrid Final |website=ATP Tour |date=7 May 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tennisnow.com/News/2022/May/Magic-Man-Alcaraz-Edges-Djokovic-for-Historic-Mad.aspx |title=Magic Man: Alcaraz Edges Djokovic for Historic Madrid Final – Tennis Now}}</ref> In the final, he went on to win his fourth title for the season (and second Masters 1000) defeating defending champion and world No. 3 [[Alexander Zverev]] thereby defeating the top three seeds in three consecutive matches. He also became the youngest champion in tournament history.<ref>{{cite tweet |author=ATP Media Info |user=ATPMediaInfo |number=1523358040761663488 |date=8 May 2022 |title=19-year-old @AlcarazCarlos03 follows wins over No. 4 Rafael Nadal and No. 1 Novak Djokovic with win over No. 3 Alexander Zverev to capture @MutuaMadridOpen title. Alcaraz becomes youngest player since start of @ATPTour in 1990 to defeat 3 Top-5 players at the same event. #MMOPEN |language=en |access-date=12 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220508174446/https://twitter.com/ATPMediaInfo/status/1523358040761663488 |archive-date=8 May 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2022-history-maker |title=History-Maker: Alcaraz Continues Rewriting The History Books |website=ATP Tour |date=9 May 2022}}</ref> As a result, he climbed to a career-high of world No. 6 in the rankings on 9 May 2022.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-zverev-madrid-2022-final-sunday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Defeats Alexander Zverev for Madrid Title | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref>

[[File:Carlos Alcaraz Wimbledon (cropped).jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|Alcaraz at the [[2022 Wimbledon Championships]]]]

Following his withdrawal from the [[2022 Italian Open – Men's singles|Italian Open]] due to an ankle injury,<ref>{{Cite news |date=9 May 2022 |title=After Madrid title, Carlos Alcaraz withdraws from Italian Open |work=[[ESPN]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/33885323/after-madrid-title-carlos-alcaraz-withdraws-italian-open |access-date=31 May 2022}}</ref> Alcaraz made his seeded debut at the [[2022 French Open – Men's singles|French Open]] as No. 6. Having won two of the tour's biggest titles on clay coming into the Slam, he was widely projected to be one of the favorites for the title.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Clarey |first=Christopher |date=21 May 2022 |title=Carlos Alcaraz Recently Beat Nadal and Djokovic on Clay. Could This French Open Be His? |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/21/sports/tennis/carlos-alcaraz-french-open.html |access-date=31 May 2022}}</ref> He defeated [[Juan Ignacio Londero]] in straight sets before saving a match point in a second round five-setter against [[Albert Ramos Viñolas]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Livaudais |first=Stephanie |date=22 May 2022 |title=Alcaraz v Londero: Things We Learned |url=https://www.rolandgarros.com/en-us/article/rg2022-things-learned-from-carlos-alcaraz-first-round-londero |access-date=31 May 2022 |website=[[French Open|Roland Garros]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Grohmann |first=Karolos |date=25 May 2022 |title=Alcaraz survives match point to beat Ramos-Vinolas in marathon |work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/alcaraz-survives-match-point-beat-ramos-vinolas-marathon-match-2022-05-25/ |access-date=31 May 2022}}</ref> He then defeated Korda and [[Karen Khachanov]] in straight sets before losing to Zverev, in the second Grand Slam quarterfinal of his career.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Livaudais |first=Stephanie |date=28 May 2022 |title=Alcaraz v Korda: Things We Learned |url=https://www.rolandgarros.com/en-us/article/rg2022-r3-carlos-alcaraz-v-sebastian-korda-things-we-learned |access-date=31 May 2022 |website=[[French Open|Roland Garros]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=29 May 2022 |title=Alcaraz Breaks New Ground With Khachanov Win In Paris |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-khachanov-roland-garros-2022-r4 |access-date=31 May 2022 |website= |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref><ref name="RG2022QF">{{Cite news |last=Clarey |first=Christopher |date=31 May 2022 |title=Alexander Zverev Beats Carlos Alcaraz at the French Open |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/31/sports/tennis/alexander-zverev-carlos-alcaraz.html |access-date=31 May 2022}}</ref>

At [[2022 Wimbledon Championships – Men's singles|Wimbledon]], Alcaraz beat [[Jan-Lennard Struff]] in a close five set match before defeating [[Tallon Griekspoor]] and [[Oscar Otte]] in straight sets, reaching the round of 16 for the first time at this major. He lost to [[Jannik Sinner]] in the fourth round.

At the [[2022 Hamburg European Open – Men's singles|Hamburg Open]], he reached the final, resulting in a new career-high of world No. 5 on 25 July 2022. Alcaraz became the youngest player to enter the top 5 in rankings since Nadal in 2005.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-molcan-hamburg-2022-sf |title=Top-5 Alcaraz Sets All-Next Gen Final with Musetti | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-top-5-pepperstone-atp-rankings-feature |title=Alcaraz Makes History, Cracks Top 5: 'It's Pretty Amazing' |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] |date=25 Jul 2022}}</ref> He was defeated in the final by [[Lorenzo Musetti]], resulting in the first loss in a tournament final of his career.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-musetti-hamburg-2022-final |title=Musetti Stuns Alcaraz In Hamburg For His First ATP Tour Title |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] |date=24 Jul 2022}}</ref> At the [[2022 Croatia Open Umag – Singles|Croatia Open]], he reached his second consecutive final, resulting in another ranking jump to world No. 4 on 1 August.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-bagnis-umag-2022-friday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Rides Hot Start into Umag SFS | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-zeppieri-umag-2022-saturday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Beats Giulio Zeppieri to Reach Umag Final | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |author=TENNIS |user=Tennis |number=1553451345411276800 |date=30 July 2022 |title=WORLD NO. 4! 💪 🇪🇸 @carlosalcaraz is projected to rise to a new career-high of No. 4 on the ATP rankings on Monday after reaching the final of Umag today, his second final in as many weeks. 🔥 The 19-year-old Spaniard had just reached No. 5 for the first time this past Monday. |language=en |access-date=12 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220730195215/https://twitter.com/tennis/status/1553451345411276800 |archive-date=30 July 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref>

Alcaraz entered the [[2022 US Open – Men's singles|2022 US Open]] as the No. 3 seed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rafael Nadal loss gives Carlos Alcaraz & Casper Ruud clear path to world No. 1 | ATP Tour | Tennis|url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-ruud-us-open-2022-world-no-1-projection}}</ref> He defeated [[Sebastian Baez]], [[Federico Coria]] and [[Jenson Brooksby]] without dropping a set to reach the fourth round.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-brooksby-us-open-2022-saturday |title=Carlos Alcaraz Defeats Jenson Brooksby at US Open | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> Next he defeated 15th seed [[Marin Cilic]] in five sets, becoming the youngest man to reach back-to-back quarterfinals at this Major in the [[Open Era]].<ref>{{cite tweet |author=US Open Tennis |user=usopen |number=1567035942849888259 |date=6 September 2022 |title=Carlitos is finding success in New York at a young age. https://t.co/fOpdx9ncC2 |language=en |access-date=12 September 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220907041535/https://twitter.com/usopen/status/1567035942849888259 |archive-date=7 September 2022 |url-status=live}}</ref> In his quarterfinal match he defeated Jannik Sinner, [[List of Grand Slam–related tennis records#Won a title after saving match points|saving a match point]] in the fourth set. The match set the record as the latest finish (at 2:50AM EST) and second longest match (5 hours and 15 minutes) in US Open history.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/article/us-open-tennis-championships-sports-new-york-jannik-sinner-49a9b96ec94a29b6deaae56dc2b54c4e |title=Alcaraz tops Sinner at 2:50 a.m.; latest US Open finish ever |website=[[Associated Press]] |date=8 September 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-us-open-2022-qf |title=Carlos Alcaraz Saves MP, Outlasts Jannik Sinner in Historic US Open QF Thriller | ATP Tour | Tennis}}</ref> He defeated [[Frances Tiafoe]] in the semifinals for his third consecutive five-set match victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com.au/tennis/story/_/id/34559302/carlos-alcaraz-races-us-open-final-5-set-win-frances-tiafoe |title=Carlos Alcaraz to play for US Open title, shot at No. 1 ranking after 5-set win over Frances Tiafoe |publisher=[[ESPN]] |date=10 September 2022 |access-date=23 September 2022}}</ref> He defeated 5th seed [[Casper Ruud]] in the final, where both players were in contention for the world No. 1 ranking, to win the title. Alcaraz became the youngest No. 1 in the history of the [[ATP Rankings]] at the age of 19 years, 4 months and 6 days, breaking [[Lleyton Hewitt]]'s record.<ref name="ATP1" /> He also became the first teenager in the Open Era to top the men's rankings and the youngest men's US Open champion since [[Pete Sampras]] in [[1990 US Open – Men's singles|1990]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/34574972/carlos-alcaraz-19-wins-us-open-become-youngest-world-no-1-men-tennis-history |title=Alcaraz, 19, wins US Open; youngest-ever No. 1 |date=11 September 2022}}</ref>

In his first match as world No. 1, Alcaraz lost his singles match at the [[2022 Davis Cup Finals]] to [[Felix Auger-Aliassime]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/davis-cup-spain-leads-canada-1-0-alcaraz-next |title=Carlos Alcaraz loses debut as world No. 1 to Felix Auger-Aliassime in Davis Cup Finals meeting |website=[[Tennis.com]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=16 September 2022 |access-date=6 November 2022}}</ref> Next, he lost to [[David Goffin]] at the [[2022 Astana Open – Singles|Astana Open]] in his opening round. Alcaraz reached the semifinals in [[2022 Swiss Indoors – Singles|Basel]], where he was defeated by the eventual champion Felix Auger-Aliassime for a second time this season.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-auger-aliassime-basel-2022-saturday |title=In-Form Felix Flies Past Alcaraz In Basel |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] |date=29 October 2022}}</ref> At the [[2022 Rolex Paris Masters – Singles|Paris Masters]], Alcaraz reached the quarterfinals after defeating [[Yoshihito Nishioka]] and [[Grigor Dimitrov]], but retired while being a set down against [[Holger Rune]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/lifestyle/sports/rune-into-paris-semi-finals-after-alcaraz-retires-2022-11-04/ |title=Rune into Paris semis after Alcaraz retires, Djokovic advances |work=[[Reuters]] |date=5 November 2022}}</ref> A day later, Alcaraz announced he had suffered an abdominal tear requiring a six-week layoff, forcing him to end his season early. Alcaraz withdrew from the [[2022 ATP Finals|ATP Finals]] and the Davis Cup Finals.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/atp-finals/2022/carlos-alcaraz-facing-six-weeks-out-with-injury-will-miss-atp-finals-and-davis-cup-in-tough-and-pain_sto9214903/story.shtml |title=CARLOS ALCARAZ FACING SIX WEEKS OUT WITH INJURY, WILL MISS ATP FINALS AND DAVIS CUP IN 'TOUGH AND PAINFUL' BLOW |work=[[Eurosport]] |first=Alex |last=Livie |date=6 November 2022}}</ref> Alcaraz, at the age of 19 years and 214 days, ended the year as youngest and first teenager world No. 1.<ref name=":0" />

===2023: 100th career win, 10th career title in Madrid ===
{{Main article|2023 Carlos Alcaraz tennis season}}
On 7 January, Alcaraz announced his withdrawal from the [[2023 Australian Open|Australian Open]] due to a hamstring injury he suffered in his right leg while training.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbssports.com/tennis/news/wta-requiring-resolution-of-peng-shuai-case-for-womens-tennis-tournaments-return-to-china/ |title=Australian Open 2023: World No. 1 Carlos Alcaraz withdraws from Grand Slam tournament due to leg injury |website=cbssports.com |date=7 January 2023}}</ref> Following the tournament, he lost the world No. 1 ranking to the champion [[Novak Djokovic]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/djokovic-pepperstone-atp-rankings-30-january-2023#:~:text=The%20Serbian%20has%20returned%20to,extending%2010th%20Australian%20Open%20crown. |title=Djokovic Returns To No. 1, Mover Of Week |date=30 January 2023 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref> He held the ranking for a total of 20 weeks.

In his first tournament back for the 2023 season at the [[Golden Swing]] in South America, Alcaraz won his seventh title at the [[2023 Argentina Open – Singles|Argentina Open]] in Buenos Aires, defeating second seed [[Cameron Norrie]]. He became the first teenager to win the event.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-norrie-buenos-aires-2023-final |title=Carlos Alcaraz Wins Buenos Aires Title in Season Debut |publisher=ATP Tour}}</ref> Defending his title at the [[2023 Rio Open – Singles|Rio Open]], he reached back to back finals, and his tenth overall as a teenager tied with [[Jimmy Connors]], [[Michael Chang]] and [[Lleyton Hewitt]].<ref>{{cite tweet |user=YoungTennisGuns |number=1629674330660429824 |date=26 February 2023 |title=Most ATP finals as a teenager in the Open era: |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230307073041/https://twitter.com/YoungTennisGuns/status/1629674330660429824?s=20 |archive-date=7 March 2023 |url-status=live}}</ref> He defeated Chilean qualifier [[Nicolás Jarry]] to reach the final, where he played against Cameron Norrie again, but lost in three sets.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-jarry-rio-2023-sf |title=Alcaraz Extends Perfect Season, Sets Norrie Rematch with Rio SF Comeback |publisher=ATP Tour}}</ref> Alcaraz was additionally scheduled to play in [[2023 Abierto Mexicano Telcel|Acapulco]] in the month of February, but withdrew prior to the tournament after suffering another hamstring injury.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.espn.com.au/tennis/story/_/id/35755117/top-seed-carlos-alcaraz-acapulco-hamstring-strain |title=Top seed Carlos Alcaraz out of Acapulco with hamstring strain |date=1 March 2023 |work=[[ESPN]] |agency=[[Reuters]] |access-date=4 March 2023}}</ref>

At the [[2023 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|Indian Wells Masters]] he recorded his 100th career win, defeating 31st seed [[Tallon Griekspoor]] to reach the fourth round, making him the second fastest player to reach this milestone after [[John McEnroe]] and faster than the [[Big Three (tennis)|Big 3]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tennishead.net/carlos-alcaraz-really-proud-to-reach-milestone-before-djokovic-nadal-and-federer |title=Carlos Alcaraz 'really proud' to reach milestone before Djokovic, Nadal and Federer |date=15 March 2023 |website=tennishead.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-100-wins-feature-2023 |title=7 Key Matches In Alcaraz's Fast Path To 100 Wins |date=14 March 2023 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref> He reached the semifinals after the retirement of [[Jack Draper (tennis)|Jack Draper]], and after defeating eighth seed [[Félix Auger-Aliassime]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-draper-indian-wells-2023-tuesday |title=Alcaraz Moves Into Indian Wells QFs After Draper Retirement |date=15 March 2023 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/carlos-alcaraz-defeats-auger-aliassime-for-first-time-in-four-tries-indian-wells |title=Carlos Alcaraz defeats Felix Auger-Aliassime for first time in four tries at Indian Wells |date=17 March 2023 |first=John |last=Berbok |website=[[tennis.com]]}}</ref> In an anticipated match, he defeated eleventh seed [[Jannik Sinner]] in straight sets to reach the final.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-indian-wells-2023-sf-preview |title=SF Preview: Alcaraz, Sinner Renew Rivalry In Indian Wells |date=17 March 2023 |access-date=25 March 2023 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.eurosport.com/tennis/atp-indian-wells/2023/carlos-alcaraz-predicts-great-rivalry-with-jannik-sinner-after-indian-wells-semi-final-win-makes-dan_sto9517951/story.shtml |title=CARLOS ALCARAZ SETS UP INDIAN WELLS FINAL WITH DANIIL MEDVEDEV AFTER BEATING JANNIK SINNER - 'YOU HAVE TO BEAT THE BEST' |date=20 March 2023 |access-date=25 March 2023 |work=[[Eurosport]]}}</ref> He won his eighth career title and third [[Masters 1000]] title over fifth seed [[Daniil Medvedev]] who was on a 19-match winning streak, becoming the first player to win the tournament without dropping a set since [[Roger Federer]] in [[2017 BNP Paribas Open – Men's singles|2017]]. He additionally became the ninth and youngest man to win both legs of the Sunshine Double. As a result, he returned to world No. 1 on 20 March 2023.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-medvedev-indian-wells-2023-final |title=Alcaraz Wins Indian Wells, Returns To World No. 1 |date=20 March 2023 |publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]]}}</ref> In [[2023 Miami Open|Miami]] where he was the defending champion, he reached the semifinals having not dropped a set defeating [[Facundo Bagnis]], [[Dušan Lajović]], 16th seed [[Tommy Paul (tennis)|Tommy Paul]] and ninth seed [[Taylor Fritz]]. This time he lost to tenth seed Jannik Sinner in three sets.<ref>{{cite web |title=Sinner Storms Back To Beat Alcaraz In Miami SF, Ending Spaniard's No. 1 Reign - Tennis |website=ATP Tour |date=1 April 2023 |url=https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-sinner-miami-2023-sf |access-date=4 April 2023}}</ref> He dropped to No. 2 in the rankings having not been able to defend his previous year title points.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jannik Sinner wins the point of the year, then ends Carlos Alcaraz's hopes for a Sunshine Double |website=Tennis.com |date=1 April 2023 |url=https://www.tennis.com/news/articles/the-point-of-the-year-by-jannik-sinner-and-carlos-alcaraz |access-date=4 April 2023}}</ref>

Alcaraz was scheduled to play at the [[Monte-Carlo Masters]] the following week but withdrew due to post-traumatic arthritis in his left hand. He began the European clay court swing at the [[Barcelona Open]], where he was the defending champion. He defeated Nuno Borges, countrymen [[Roberto Bautista Agut]] and [[Alejandro Davidovich Fokina]], [[Dan Evans (tennis)|Dan Evans]] in the semifinals, and [[Stefanos Tsitsipas]] in the final to successfully defend his title without dropping a set. It also marked his third title of the season. He won his tenth career title at the [[2023 Mutua Madrid Open]] over lucky loser [[Jan-Lennard Struff]] where he was the defending champion. He became the sixth-youngest player to reach 10 tour-level titles in the [[Open Era]].<ref>https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-madrid-2023-final-reaction</ref>
At the next clay court tournament, the [[Rome Masters]], Alcaraz earned the opportunity to clinch the world No. 1 ranking by playing his second round match. Following his victory, he regained the top ranking from Novak Djokovic. However, he was upset in the next round by the world No. 135 [[Fabian Marozsan]] in straight sets.<ref>https://www.atptour.com/en/news/alcaraz-marozsan-rome-2023-monday</ref>

==Playing style==
Alcaraz is an [[All-court player|all-court]], [[All-rounder (tennis)|all-round]] tennis player, but primarily employs an aggressive baseline style of play, with an emphasis on a high winner count from his [[forehand]], typically his most reliable and potent shot. He can either hit his forehand flat and fast for winners from every court position, or add a great amount of topspin and margin over the net. He also possesses a well-rounded and more flat and lower net-clearance [[backhand]] groundstroke that he is able to redirect down the line for clean winners. His greatly disguised [[drop shot]] is key to his game, as he often combines the heaviness of his groundstrokes that pushes his opponents back into the court into a defensive position, with a drop shot that is often too well-placed and disguised to deal with. He has an impressive net-game with great drop volleys and drive volleys, and frequently serve-and-volleys on crucial points.{{citation needed|date=September 2022}}

His first serve is hit at high speeds with little emphasis on service box placement, typically at around 210 km/h (130 mph). This has led to some criticism of his serving. However, he has an excellent and reliable second serve to which he can add topspin, in order to get a high bounce off the court and either push back or get a weak return from closer-returning opponents. This serve typically reaches 150 to 170 km/h (93 to 106 mph).{{citation needed|date=September 2022}}

Alcaraz has earned acclaim for his remarkable athletic and physical traits. In particular, his direct sprints, counterattacking abilities from often indefensible positions on court, and an extremely high peak [[footspeed]] which has earned him comparisons to a young [[Rafael Nadal]] and [[Gaël Monfils]]. He has earned comparisons to [[Novak Djokovic]] for his assured lateral movement and court-coverage aided by physical splits and sliding through the court on defense, particularly on his backhand side where he is often able to neutralize his opponent's groundstroke aggression or drop shot attempts. He has also earned comparisons, on occasion, to [[Roger Federer]] for his great footwork and ability to go inside-out on his forehand and control the court with his offense.{{citation needed|date=September 2022}}
